lines.text: Well my dear, I take it you spend quite a lot of time in the saddle.
Yes, I love an early morning ride.
Well, I'm an early riser myself.
[Zorin is going to kill Bond]
My department knows I'm here. When I don't report they'll retaliate.
If you're the best they've got, they're more likely to try and cover up your embarrassing incompetence.
Don't count on it, Zorin.

[laughs]
Ha ha, you amuse me, Mr. Bond.
It's not mutual.
What have they done?
You discharged her, so she and her accomplice came here to kill you. Then they set fire to the office, to conceal the crime but they were trapped in the elevator and perished in the flames.
But that means I would have to be...
Dead!
[shoots him]
That's rather neat, Don't you think?
Brilliant. I'm almost speechless with admiration.
Intuitive improvisation is the secret of genius.
Herr Doktor Mortner would be proud of his creation.
[Hovering over San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge in their airship]
Wow! What a view!
To a KILL!
[after dropping the tycoon out of the airship]
So, anyone else want to drop out?
[the morning after Bond sleeps with May Day]
You slept well?
A little restless but I got off eventually.
Taxi!
No, no, no English!

[Pulling him from the car]
Out!
Another wealthy owner?
Who knows? But she certainly bares closer inspection.
We're on a mission.
Sir Godfrey, on a mission, I am expected to sacrifice myself!
More. More power. More. Do it!
Hello. I thought you might like to join the party. By the way, the name is James St. John Smythe. I'm English.
I never would have guessed.
You're under arrest.
Wait a minute, this is James Stock of the London Financial times.
Well, actually, captain, I'm with the British Secret Service. The name is Bond, James Bond.
Is he?
Are you?
Yes.
And I'm Dick Tracy and you're still under arrest!
It's time to flood the fault.
But May Day and my men!
Yes. A convenient coincidence.
Mr. Zorin, those men are LOYAL to you!
[Scarpine knocks him out]
Qu'est-ce qu'il y a, monsieur?
There's a fly in his soup!
He's the outstanding horse of the sales. We expect him to fetch over three million dollars!
Oh, sounds quite reasonable!
[Bond is released from jail in Paris for violating the Napoleonic Code]

[to Bond]
May I remind you that this operation was to be conducted discreetly. All it took was six million Francs in damages and penalties for violating most of the Napoleonic Code.
Well, under the circumstances, sir, I thought it MORE IMPORTANT to identify the assassin.
What did you learn from Aubergine before his untimely demise?

[to M]
Well, only that Zorin is having a thoroughbred sale at his stud farm not far from here. I think I should be there.
[to Tibbett]
Can you help me with that, Sir Godfrey?
It may be possible to arrange an invitation. It's a bit short notice, but I might just be able to squeeze you in, Bond.

[to Tibbett]
Thank you, sir.
Get Zorin for me!
[May Day walks into her room and finds Bond naked in her bed]
May Day, where have you been? I've been waiting for you... to take care of me, personally.
[Zorin nods to May Day, and she enters silently in the room]
I see you're a woman of very few words.
What's there to say?

Gentlemen, for centuries alchemists tried to make gold from base metals. Today, we make microchips from sillicon, which is common sand; but far better than gold. Now, for several years, we had a profitable partnership, you as manufacturers, while I acquired and passed on to you industrial information that made you competitive, succesful. We are now in the unique position to form an international cartel to control not only production, but distribution of these microchips. There is one obstacle - Sillicon Valley in San Francisco. Over 250 plants, employing thousands of scientists, technicians. This is the heartland of electronic production in the United States - which accounts for, what, 80% - of the world microchip market. I propose to - *end* - the domination of Silicon Valley and leave us in control of that market.
She must take a lot of vitamins!
Yes, and perhaps Pegasus does too.
You lost, 007.

[after looking at Tibbett's body]
Killing Tibbett was a mistake.
Then I'm about to make that same mistake twice.
You have exactly 35 minutes to get properly dressed, 007.
[Bond checks the tie on his suit]
I take it you ride.
I'm happiest in the saddle.
A fellow sportsman. So, what about fishing? Fly-casting?

[realizes he's been trapped]
I'm neglecting my other guests. Enjoy yourself, you'll find the young ladies stimulating company.
The bubbles tickle my... Tchaikovsky!

[Bond has just received the Order of Lenin from General Gogol]
The order of Lenin, for Comrade Bond. The first ever non-Soviet citizen to receive this award.
I'd thought the KGB would have celebrated if Silicon Valley had been destroyed.
On the contrary, Admiral, where would Russian research be without it?
[Bond is dangling from an unlocked fire engine ladder]
Turn!
[Stacey turns]
Not this way! That way!
Welcome, sir. I'm Jenny Flex.
Of course you are.

[on being betrayed by Zorin]
... And I thought that creep loved me!
[last lines]
[Bond is in the shower with Stacey and Q is using Snooper to spy on them]
007 alive.
Where is he? What's he doing?
Just cleaning up a few details.
Oh, James!
Somebody will take care of you.
Oh, you'll see to that personally, will you?
This will hurt him more than me.

[sees Bond disguised as a fireman]
Where's the fire?

[American accent]
In your rear end!
[Bond is gettting ready to have a horse race with Zorin]
And what if I'm thrown?
Then you lose.

[First lines]
I thought you'd never get back.
Well, there was a heck of a crowd on the piste!
So I see. Mission accomplished?
Best beluga.
[Kimberly laughs]
Vodka, rather shaken, and one microchip.
Good. I'll send a signal to M.
Be a good girl would you, and put her on automatic. And we could do with a couple of glasses.
They're in the overhead rack.
[Bond pulls a lever and Kimberley falls on the sofa with him]
Commander Bond.

[Bond unzips her outfit]
Call me James. It's five days to Alaska.
[they start kissing]
What's this thing loaded with?
Rock salt.
Now you tell me!
James, that night in London when I was with the Bolshoi...
Ah, what a performance.
In my dressing room, later, did you know I was an agent with orders to seduce you?
Why do you think I sent you three dozen *red* roses?
Mmm. Now, that *was* a performance.
Intercept murder suspect in a stolen fire truck. He MAY be armed... and he's SURE dangerous!
Long time no see, James...!
[she giggles]
... Oh, you haven't changed a bit!
Well, YOU have. You're even LOVELIER.
[Bond and Aubergine are discussing the use of steriods in Zorin's horses]
Tell me, why do Zorin's horses beat others with far superior bloodlines?
This is a mystery.
Could he be using drugs?
Nothing showed up in the tests.
[a mystery person is seen entering the room]
Later this month, Zorin will hold his annual sales at his stud farm near Paris. Security is formidable.
[the mystery person attacks another person dressed in black. The butterflies in the room go stir crazy]
But the key to this mystery is there. And I, Achille Aubergine, will intend to find it.
[We get a good look at the eyes of the mystery person. Aubergine is suddenly stabbed in the cheek with a hook and his head falls to the table]
[At Stacey Sutton's home, Bond cooks dinner; pulls out a excellent quiche from the oven]
Et voilà. Quiche des Cabinet.
Sounds interesting. Mmm. What is it?
An omelet.
[Stacey chuckles]
Now, you were telling me about your grandfather.
He left Sutton Oil to Dad, who expected me, as the only child, to take it over someday. So, at college, I studied geology.
And then what happened?
all the cash, all the furniture, everything. So I took this job as state geologist. And I've just managed to hold on to this house and-and my shares.
Well, that's what the $5 million were for, your shares?
Ten times more than they're worth. Just, uh...
[grabs the check]
just drop the lawsuit and shut my mouth. I haven't accepted yet.
So Zorin sent along his gorillas to help you make up your mind.
They have.
[tears up the check; sighs]
I'd sell everything and live in a tent before I give up.
I'll fill you in later, Moneypenny.
Now that we're all here, you can get on with the briefing, Q.
Very good, sir. Gentlemen, a silicon integrated circuit. The essential part of all modern computers.
No lecture, Q. We're all aware of the usefulness of the microchip.
Well, now, until recently, all microchips were susceptible to damage from the intense magnetic pulse of a nuclear explosion.
Magnetic pulse?

Yes, Minister. I burst in outer space over the UK and everything with a microchip in it, from, well, the modern toaster to the most sophisticated computers in our defense systems would we rendered absolutely useless.

a chip totally impervious to magnetic pulse damage. Now, if I place it on the micro-comparator and compare it with a chip that Commander Bond recovered from the body of 003 in Siberia, when I bring the two images together...
They're identical. The KGB must have pipeline into that research company.
With the cane, is that Max Zorin?
Yes. Born in Dresden. Fled from East Germany in the 60s. Changed passport. Speaks at least five languages, no accent. Now, the talk of the city and the bourse.
The old rags to riches story.
He made his first fortune in oil and gas, James. Now, second in electronics and high tech.

[At a horse race]
Come on Fluke! Get a wiggle on!
Bollinger '75.
I see you are a connoisseur, Monsieur Bond.
Excellent choice.
I am pleased you approve, since you are paying the bill. Cheers.
Santé, Monsieur Aubergine.
By the way, the name is St. John Smythe, James St. John Smythe.
Dr. Carl Mortner, at your service.
You will come back to us, comrade. No one ever *leaves* the KGB.
Mortner?
Got a real winner here. His name is actually Hans Glaub - the German pioneer who developed steroids.
That ties him to the horse injection.
During World War II he experimented with steroids on pregnant women in the concentration camps in an attempt to enhance intelligence.
With any success?
Eventually every mother aborted - though a handful of children were produced with phenomenal IQs. But there was a side effect - they were psychotics .
Was this Mortner - or Glaub, tried by the war crimes commission?
The Russians grabbed him. Set him up in a laboratory. He spent several years developing steroids for their athletes.
Pola Ivanova!
James Bond!
Détente can be beautiful.
This is no time - to be discussing - politics.

[Bond posing as a London Financial Times reporter]
If you'd like any further information, just call me, Mr, eh?
Stock, James Stock. Thank you Mr. Howe.
I'm Stacey - Sutton. And you're a reporter. Eh, what was it?
Stock, James Stock.
I only have a few leftovers in the fridge. I'm a pathetic cook.
Well, I'll lend a hand.
You can cook?
I've been known to dabble.
It's women's lib. They're taking over the teamsters.
I should take a closer look at that mine.
What's stopping you?
Will you keep still!
Do you know what I'm sitting on?
I'm trying not to think about it.
Stacey, are you there?
You betcha!
